image_2024-04-01_161157409 404×720 326 KB

Our pinion gears got stuck directly on the kraken shaft, we do not believe that there is anything between the shaft and the pinion’s mount/hole. This was being run on our shooter, and it was spinning on some very sketchy gears, but we don’t know how to get it off and also save the shaft.

posts.custom_user_title: Design team captain, Build team member

posts.cooked: When you put these on they just slid on right?

posts.name: Jose Hernandez
posts.cooked: Yeah, they fit on normally, but now they will not come off with even a seriously crazy amount of pulling

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: And we’re the gears in line when installed? The teeth all lined up? The top one was NOT half a tooth off relative to the bottom one?

posts.name: Jose Hernandez
posts.cooked: Yeah, the gears were placed on normally, they were removed previously and fit back on just as well.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Design team captain, Build team member

posts.custom_user_title: Design team captain, Build team member

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Your mechanism that interfaces with these gear teeth - is it more than one? Does the top gear power something and the bottom gear spins something else?

Regardless - it appears you either twisted the shaft or sheared spline teeth and spun a gear on the kraken shaft. If you can get it off that section of shaft is likely unusable and would need cutting off.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Some light tapping on the side of the gear could loosen them to come off

posts.name: Alex Richards
posts.cooked:
Combine this with some heat and you should be able to grip the pinion with a pair of vice-grips and pull. A small butane torch will heat up the pinion and make it expand slightly.

Make sure to use pliers or vice grips to pull the gear off after you heat it. Don’t ask how I learned that
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: Jose Hernandez
posts.cooked: Thank you, sorry for getting back late but this really worked well. I wasn’t present when they took off them but my team said they heated it up and sprayed the shaft with Compressed air after heating it up.
